awd_titl_txt: OPUS:CRS:  Global Change and California Birds and Mammals Across Centuries - The Grinnell Resurvey Project
awd_abstract_narration:
Most studies of the effects of 20th century environmental change on animals focus on shifts in the timing of their activities, such as breeding and migration, or develop forecasts of the future distribution of species using models based on the climate that species currently occupy. Few studies have directly measured the long-term impacts of environmental and land use change on the occurrences of species. This research will produce a synthesis with two important objectives: (1) Bring together the results of 28 core articles from different published studies into a book that synthesizes the entirety of Grinnell Resurvey Project for the general public, land managers, scientific colleagues, and "students of the future" who will resurvey these places again in 25-30 years after much greater levels of environmental change; and (2) Produce a statewide portrait of change over the past century for California's birds. Using the species-specific estimates of local colonization and extinction derived from multispecies occupancy models in conjunction with projections of climate and land-use change, the research will forecast future avian distributions, in order to evaluate species and regions of concern and the degree to which bird communities will change, which will be communicated to the public through outreach publications as well as to natural resource agencies through a workshop. 

The Grinnell Resurvey Project has been reconstructing a historic baseline of bird and mammal diversity in California from surveys done by Joseph Grinnell and colleagues in the early 1900's before anthropogenic climate change began. Their records include >100,000 specimens, 74,000 pages of field notes with bird count and mammal trapping data, and 10,000 images. Since 2004, members of the Grinnell Resurvey Project have been walking in Grinnell's footsteps throughout California - from the lowest point in the contiguous US in Death Valley to near its highest on Mt. Whitney - and conducting resurveys to document directly the effects of a century of environmental change on birds and mammals. The project has now retraced enough of Grinnell's footsteps throughout California's diverse environments and developed appropriate methods for working with these data to produce a credible synthesis. Measures of change in the occupancy of species, derived directly from resurveys at the same historic locations, will be linked to measures of climate, land-use and other global changes, and used to forecast future impacts on species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
I lead a team that has been reconstructing a historic baseline of early 20th century bird and mammal diversity in California from surveys done by Joseph Grinnell and colleagues that include >100,000 specimens, 74,000 pages of field notes with historic bird count and mammal trapping data, and 10,000 images. Since 2004, we have been walking in Grinnell?s footsteps throughout the state ? from the lowest point in the contiguous US in Death Valley to near its highest elevation on Mt. Whitney ? and conducting resurveys to document the effects of a century of environmental change on the birds and mammals. Supported in large part by multiple NSF grants, the ultimate goal of our Grinnell Resurvey Project is to quantify faunal change over the past century, relate it to measures of climate, land-use and other global changes, and use these direct measures of change to forecast future impacts. We have now retraced enough of Grinnell?s footsteps throughout California?s diverse environments, developed appropriate methods for working with these data, and completed a large set of core studies to allow us to produce a credible synthesis and statewide analysis based on direct measures of century of faunal change, which will influence our understanding of global change.

Key scientific outcomes supported by this grant include: (1) an examination of how exposure to climate change drove the stability or collapse of desert mammal and bird communities, respectively, over the past century.  The small mammal community showed remarkable stability and resilience, while the bird community at the same sites supports 40% fewer species in response to a century of drying and warming; (2) a synthesis of the evidence linking species? traits to contemporary range shifts, which found traits of species are weak predictors of whether or not they will shift their geographic ranges over decades to a century of exposure to climate change; (3) development of a framework for understanding co-tolerance of species to land-use and climate change, and how the concept of concordant and opposing effects of threats results in the net impacts of climate and land-use change on contemporary assemblages; and (4) production of a statewide portrait of change over the past century for California?s birds identified challenges in forecasting future avian distributions due to greatly different performance of models with different constructions and assumptions, suggesting that forecasting is likely to lead to uncertain outcomes.  Our future research will identify clear steps moving forward that can identify regions of concern and whether assemblages will be restructured to form novel communities of birds will be formed in 50 years.

 Products that addressed the needs of management agencies and outreach to the general public included: (1) Holding a virtual workshop with managers and scientists working at the key US National Park units in California's Mojave Desert where we have conducted Grinnell Resurveys to present our results and discuss their implications for management of these important landscapes; (2) Presenting at a virtual workshop on climate change3 indicators for the California Environmental Protection Agency; (3) Conserving all of the survey data produced from the Grinnell Resurvey Project on the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology's web portal that is publicly available.


Last Modified: 12/28/2022
Modified by: Steven R Beissinger

Whitney ? and conducting resurveys to document the effects of a century of environmental change on the birds and mammals. Our future research will identify clear steps moving forward that can identify regions of concern and whether assemblages will be restructured to form novel communities of birds will be formed in 50 years.
